title: Adding uniqueness index over multiple columns
content: add_index :subscriptions, [:user_id, :content_id], unique: true

content: RAILS_ENV=production bundle exec rake token:generate

title: Check if all letters in string are uppercase
content:
Simply compare the string with itself uppercased:
is_upper = str == str.uppcase

title: Allowing CORS in Rails --api
content:
If you want to allow requests from the frontend part running on http://localhost:8080, in Gemfile uncomment gem 'rack-cors' and in config/initializers/cors.rb uncomment the following:
Rails.application.config.middleware.insert_before 0, Rack::Cors do
  allow do
    origins 'localhost:8080'
    resource '*',
    headers: :any,methods: %i(get post put patch delete options head)
  end
end
Don't forget to set correct port to 8080.

title: Check if the user is active when using Devise
content:
If you want to add a sign to the user model holding the value if the user is active or not and you are using Devise, just add this to the user model:
def active_for_authentication?
  super && self.your_method_for_checking_active # i.e. super && self.is_active
end

def inactive_message
  'Sorry, this account has been deactivated.'
end

title: Creating many-to-many join table
content:
Easy hint how to create many-to-many join table in migration:
def change
  # This is enough; you don't need to worry about order
  create_join_table :categories, :users

  # If you want to add an index for faster querying through this join:
  create_join_table :categories, :users do |t|
    t.index :category_id
    t.index :user_id
  end
end

title: Grouping items before printed with 'fields_for'
content:
If you have a collection of related entities and you want to print them grouped, you can use field_for like this:
<dl>
  <% @order.order_items.group_by { |oi| p.product }.each do |product, order_items_group| %>
    <dt><%= product.name %></dt>
    <%= f.fields_for :order_items_group, order_items_group.sort_by { |oi| oi.id } do |builder| %>
      <dd>$<%= builder.object.price %>,-</dd>
    <% end %>
  <% end %>
</dl>

title: Loading 'Lib' folder in production
content:
If you want to load Lib folder in production as well, use 
config.eager_load_paths += Dir["#{config.root}/lib/**/"]
instead of 
config.autoload_paths += Dir["#{config.root}/lib/**/"]

title: Flash messages are showing twice
content:
If flash messages are showing twice, it is probably because the render method was called to show the view, but the flash messages are deleted only after calling the redirect_to method.
If you want the flash message to be shown after the redirect_to use flash[]. If you want to show it in the current request (after render) use flash.now[] instead.

title: Solving "Incomplete response received from application"
content:
When you deploy Rails application to nginx / passenger and you get Incomplete response received from application you don't have secret_key_base set:
  • Navigate to root of your project and run bundle exec rake secret RAILS_ENV=production
  • Open config/secrets.yml file and under production replace the value of the secret_key_base with the recently copied secret
  • run passenger-config restart-app and select the app you are fixing

title: Select helper for Rails model enum
content:
<%= f.select :color, Product.colors.keys, {}, class: 'form-control' %>

# with I18n localization:
<%= f.select :color, Product.colors.keys.map { |key| [t("activerecord.attributes.product.colors.#{key}"), key] }, {}, class: 'form-control' %>

title: Validate only when custom condition is met
content:
You can trigger a model validation only when the condition is met by two ways:
# using a Proc:
validates :email, presence: true, if: Proc.new { |user| user.approved? }

# using a method:
validates :address, presence: true, if: :some_complex_condition

def some_complex_condition
  true # do your checking and return true or false
end

title: Adding custom flash message types
content:
Flash messages accept any symbol, but for redirect_to method only :notice and :alert symbols are accepted by default.
If you want to add another symbols, you can do so by:
class ApplicationController < ActionController::Base
  add_flash_types :error, ...
and than you can use it like:
redirect_to root_path, error: 'Some error'

title: Working with enums in Rails
content:
Specifying enum in model:
enum status: [ :draft, :in_progress, :done ]
Specifying enum in model with default values:
#Note the change of square brackets to braces
enum status: { draft: 0, in_progress: 1, done: 2 }
Specifying of default value in migration:
add_column :tables, :status, :integer, default: 0

title: Getting parameters from request.referer
content:
For getting parameters from request.referer: 
url = URI(request.referer)
params = CGI.parse(url.query)
id = params["id"]

title: Validation messages without a field name
content:
If you want validation messages without leading field name change it in localization folder:
en:
  errors:
    format: "%{message}"
Default is format: %{attribute} %{message}

title: Adding reference with the different column name
content:
Sometimes you may want to add a reference to an another model, but wit different attribute and db field name. Like you want to add a reference to a User model, but with attribute name (and db field name) author:
# The migration when creating new table:
t.references :author, index: true, foreign_key: { to_table: :users }

# The migration when updating existing table:
add_reference :posts, :author, foreign_key: { to_table: :users }

# The model
belongs_to :author, class_name: 'User'

title: Adding field sizes in migrations
content:
For adding field sizes in database you can specify it in migrations like this:
class Init < ActiveRecord::Migration[5.1]
  def change
    create_table :tests do |t|
      t.string :name, limit: 100
      t.decimal :price, precision: 18, scale: 5
    end
  end
end

title: Querying for all users with a specific role
content:
User can have multiple roles and each role can be assigned to multiple users. Thus it is a has_and_belongs_to_many relation.
To query all users with a specific role:
User.joins(:roles).where(roles: {id: role_id})

title: Setting M:N relations by checkboxes
content:
If you have a M:N relation like between User and Role (user can have multiple roles and each role can be assigned to multiple users), than you may want to set a relation between those two by checkboxes:
<%= f.collection_check_boxes(:role_ids, Role.all, :id, :name) do |r| %>
  <%= r.check_box class: 'form-item' %> <%= r.text %>
<% end %>
Migration:
class CreateRolesUsers < ActiveRecord::Migration[5.1]
  def change
    create_table :roles_users do |t|
      t.references :user, foreign_key: true
      t.references :role, foreign_key: true
    end
  end
end
Setting strong parameters in controller:
params.require(:user).permit(:name, {role_ids: []})

title: Including related entities of related entities
content: posts = Post.includes(comments: [:author]).all

title: ActiveSupport#delegate
content:
If you have multiple nested objects, it can be tricky to check all of them not being nil.
#can get NoMethodsError when the client is nil
order.client.address
You can use ActiveSupport#delegate like this to avoid the problem, which will create a order.client_address for you:
class Order
  delegate :address, to: :client, prefix: true, allow_nil: true
end
Moreover it is more readable and not violating the Law of Demeter.

title: Nested attributes duplicate models when editing
content:
When using accepts_nested_attributes_for you must insert nested model's :id in strong parameters to avoid creating duplicates:
def params_update
  params.require(:parent_model).permit(:first_attribute, :second_attribute, child_attributes: [:id, :another_child_attribute])
end

title: Scoped associations
content:
class User
  has_many :orders
  has_many :active_orders, -> { active }, class_name: 'Order'
end

You can even use such scope in .includes method
users = User.includes(:active_orders).where(orders: { user_id: current_user.id })

title: POST links are not working
content:
If the <%= link_to 'Some Link', some_path, method: :post %> is not working, check you have jquery and jquery_ujs loaded in application.js:
//= require jquery
//= require jquery_ujs

title: Passing error flash message to 'redirect_to' method
content:
Only :notice and :alert are by default accepted as flash keys passed to redirect_to method. To show :error:
redirect_to my_path, :flash => { :error => 'My error message' }

title: Private associations
content:
It is possible to set the assocations private:
class Order < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :order_items, :dependent => :destroy
  private :order_items, :order_items=
end

title: Looping through array by pairs
Get rid of 'field_with_errors' wrappers
content:
When submitting a form and the validation doesn't pass, invalid fields are wrapped by <div class="field_with_errors">.
You can get rid of it by the following piece of code in config/environment.rb file:
ActionView::Base.field_error_proc = Proc.new do |html_tag, inst|
  html_tag.html_safe
end

title: Dumping actual db schema into a scheme.rb and restoring it
content: When a new environment is setting up, it's not needed run all migrations one by one. You can create a dump of actual database schema by running rails db:schema:dump and later restoring it by rails db:schema:load

content:

Removing: remove_column :table_name, :column_name
*table names are in plural

title: Checking if the related entity is nil
content:
This is checking a property value:

def has_object?
  object_id.nil?
end
but this will trigger a sql query:
def has_object?
  object.nil?
end
sql query:
SELECT  "objects".* FROM "objects"
WHERE "objects"."object_id" = $1 LIMIT $2

content:
rails generate migration AddAttributeToModel attribute:datatype

This will generate a migration adding an attribute to a model

title: Let Webrick (RoR server) serve static files
content:
You can use Webrick to serve static files like index.html.
Navigate console to the folder you want to serve and run the command:
ruby -run -e httpd . -p 9000

Open browser on address http://localhost:9000
